NATIONAL ASSOCIATION OF EDUCATIONAL BROADCASTING
1346 Connecticut Avenue, N.W.
Vfeshington, D. C. 20036
MEMORANDUM
To: Office of Education
July 30 1964
STATUS OF PROJECT OE 3-I6-OO7
and
REQUEST FOR AMEINDMENT AND EXTENSION OF THE PROJECT
Under this contract, the NAEB is preparing and producing six "kits" of
information about the utilization of television lessons in the classroom.
Each kit will contain a 30-minute l6mm sound film together with correlated
materials such as discussion outlines, bibliographies, and general back¬
ground information. The kits are designed to provide the basis for a
meeting or class session relating to some phase of utilization.
The kits are being prepared in such a way that they can be used in sequence
or individually for special interest meetings. They will be particularly
appropriate for seminars and summer workshops in educational television.
CURRENT STATUS OP THE PROJECT
The NAEB was awarded a contract to produce these materials on January 30,
1963. The scheduled termination date for the contract is August 31, 1964.
As a result of the first Advisory Committee meeting, specific outlines
were developed and an agreement was made to secure the services of a
writer who could develop these outlines into script treatments. As the
treatments were prepared and reviewed by the Committee, it became
apparent that the use of video tape and kinescope film for the production
of these materials as originally contemplated would not provide a satis¬
factory technical process for the production of superior materials.
Therefore, at the request of the Advisory Committee, the Project Staff
was directed to discuss with the U.S. Office of Education an amendment
to the contract which would provide additional funds to produce these
materials directly on film. The discussions between the National
Association of Educational Broadcasters and the Office of Education were
conducted during a four month period and resulted in an amendment to the
contract dated September 15, I963, calling for film production, although
it was acknowledged that this would most likely require a lengthier
production schedule than videotape and kinescope.
